Subgroup

Let $G$ be a monoid. A subset $H \subset G$ is called a submonoid if $H$ satisfies the following conditions: (i) $e \in H$, (ii) $a, b \in H \Longrightarrow a b \in H$. If $G$ is a group, $H$ is called a subgroup of $G$ if in addition, (iii) $a \in H \Longrightarrow a^{-1} \in H$. In particular, a subgroup of a group $G$ is a submonoid that is closed under the process of taking inverses. In defining a subgroup $H \subset G$, condition (i) can be weakened by simply requiring $H \neq \emptyset$, since this implies $e \in H$ using (ii) and (iii). Of course, similar reasoning is not possible for monoids. Every group $G$ admits $\{e\}$ and $G$ as trivial subgroups. Given $m \in \mathbb{Z}$, the set $m \mathbb{Z}$ consisting of all integral multiples of $m$ is a subgroup of the additive group $\mathbb{Z}$. We will see in 1.3/4 that all subgroups of $\mathbb{Z}$ are of this type. More generally, every element $a$ of a group $G$ gives rise to a so-called cyclic subgroup of $G$. It consists of all powers $a^{n}, n \in \mathbb{Z}$, where we put $a^{n}=\left(a^{-1}\right)^{-n}$ for $n<0; see also Section 1.3.
Ring

A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.
Division Ring
A ring R is called a division ring or a skew field if R is not the zero ring and every nonzero element of R is a unit (R* = R - {0}).
Finitely Generated Ideal
An ideal $\mathfrak{a}$ in a ring $R$ is finitely generated if it admits a finite system of generators.
Euclidean function
The map $\delta$ in a Euclidean domain $R$ that facilitates the Euclidean division process.
A-module

An A-module is an abelian group M, together with an exterior multiplication A x M -> M, (a, x) -> a.x that satisfies the vector space axioms: a.(x+y) = a.x + a.y, (a+b).x = a.x + b.x, a.(b.x) = (ab).x, 1.x = x for elements a, b in A, x, y in M.
Purely Inseparable Extension
A purely inseparable extension is a field extension where the minimal polynomial of any element in the extension has a single root, which is repeated according to the degree of the polynomial.
Frobenius homomorphism

For a field $K$ of characteristic $p>0$, the map $\sigma: K \longrightarrow K, \quad a \longmapsto a^{p}$, which respects the addition on $K$, defines a homomorphism of fields known as the Frobenius homomorphism of $K$.
Splitting field of Family of Polynomials

A splitting field of a family of nonconstant polynomials \\(\mathfrak{F}=(f_i)_{i \in I}, f_i \in K[X]\\) over a field \\(K\\) is a field \\(L\\) extending \\(K\\) such that: (i) Every polynomial \\(f_i\\) decomposes into a product of linear factors over \\(L\\). (ii) The extension \\(L / K\\) is generated by the zeros of the polynomials \\(f_i\\).
Noetherian ring

A ring \(R\) is called Noetherian if every ascending chain of ideals \(\mathfrak{a}_{1} \subset \mathfrak{a}_{2} \subset \ldots \subset R\) becomes stationary after finitely many steps, or equivalently, every ideal of \(R\) is finitely generated.
p-Sylow subgroup

A subgroup H of a finite group G is called a p-Sylow subgroup if H is a p-group such that p does not divide the index (G: H). This means there exist integers k, m in N satisfying ord H=p^k, as well as ord G=p^k m, where p does not divide m.
Codomain
The codomain of a function is the set that contains all potential output values, even if some of those values are not actually produced by any input in the domain.
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A subgroup is defined as a subset of a group that satisfies certain conditions. Therefore, the concept of a group must be defined to understand what a subgroup is.
A division ring is a specific type of ring where every nonzero element is a unit. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a division ring is.

An ideal is a subset of a ring that satisfies certain properties. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what an ideal is, and by extension, what a finitely generated ideal is.

A Euclidean function is defined in the context of a Euclidean domain, which is a specific type of ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a Euclidean domain and its Euclidean function are.

An A-module is an abelian group with an additional structure defined by an exterior multiplication with elements from a ring A. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what an A-module is.
A purely inseparable extension is a type of field extension. Therefore, the concept of a field must be defined to understand what a purely inseparable extension is.
The Frobenius homomorphism is a map defined for fields of characteristic p>0. Therefore, the concept of a field must be defined to understand what the Frobenius homomorphism is.

A splitting field is a field extension that satisfies certain properties with respect to a family of polynomials. Therefore, the concept of a field must be defined to understand what a splitting field is.
A Noetherian ring is a specific type of ring where every ideal is finitely generated. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a Noetherian ring is.
A p-Sylow subgroup is a specific type of subgroup of a finite group. Therefore, the concept of a subgroup must be defined to understand what a p-Sylow subgroup is.
